div.p:
EC-OpenShift plugin integrates with the OpenShift container platform allowing you to coordinate and manage microservices-based applications deployments and releases on both on-premise and hosted OpenShift offerings.
In case of on-premise setup, plugin helps you install OpenShift Origin on VMWare setup right from importing underlying hosts (VMs) from OVF template, installing OpenShift Origin using Ansible scripts and performs post installation steps like creation of project, service accout and router (with same name as project name). This makes deployment of any micro-service simple and straight forward. For the detailed requirements about OVF template, see procedure details.
Plugin also supports various installation topologies based on requirements. Supported topologies are:
Minimal : Sets up one OpenShift master, embedded etcd and user supplied number of nodes. Suitable for setting up OpenShift cluster for evaluation purpose or for development setup.
Multiple Etcd : Sets up one OpenShift master, separate cluster of three etcd instances and user supplied number of nodes.
Multiple Etcd + HAProxy : Highly available setup with three OpenShift masters, cluster of three etcd instances and user supplied number of nodes. Suitable for production environment.
For hosted OpenShift offerings, plugin assumes that you have a service account which has full access on projects that you intend to use through this plugin.

ol.li: RedHat OpenShift 3 cluster - RedHat OpenShift Online, RedHat OpenShift Dedicated, or RedHat OpenShift On-premise.

A service account with cluster access on RedHat OpenShift Dedicated - The service account token will be used to authenticate against the Kubernetes and OpenShift APIs for managing projects (namespaces) and deploying services. In case of on-premise setup, Provision Cluster procedure creates service account and stores the service token by creating a new plugin configuration. User does not have to separatly create plugin configuration.

div.p: Plugin configurations are sets of parameters that apply across some or all of the plugin procedures. They reduce repetition of common values, create predefined parameter sets for end users, and securely store credentials where needed. Each configuration is given a unique name that is entered in designated parameters on procedures that use them.
To create plugin configurations in ElectricFlow, do these steps:

ul.li: Go to Administration > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Click Configure to open the OpenShift Configurations page.
Enter the following configuration parameters for communicating with the OpenShift cluster:

tr.td: Provide a unique name for the configuration, keeping in mind that you may need to create additional configurations over time.
The endpoint at which OpenShift API can be reached. Must be an IP address or a resolvable DNS name.

Name: Service account name.
Private Key: Provide the bearer token for the service account that has access to create resources in the OpenShift cluster. This bearer token will be used to deploying services on the OpenShift cluster.
Log level to use for logging output. Error=4, Warning=3, Info=2, Debug=1. Info by default.

div.p: IMPORTANT: For all parameter descriptions below, required parameters are shown in bold italics. Please note that some of names given in ElectricFlow UI will be modified to comply with the naming conventions of Kubernetes. Specifically characters such as "space , _ " will be converted to "-". Such parameters are marked with an asterisk (*).

The procedure checks if the OpenShift cluster exists and is reachable with provided details. If not, then provisions a new one.
The procedure uses ESX plugin's import procedure to setup underlying VMs.For system requirements, see here.For networking requirements, see here.
Once VMs are available, procedure uses ansible scripts provided by OpenShift to setup openshift cluster.
Bellow are the prerequisite to use this procedure:
Ansible (v2.2.0.0) must be installed on ElectricFlow agent machines and 'ansible-playbook' command should be included in PATH.
ElectricFlow agent machine should have passwordless SSH access to imported VMs.
Plugin passes the hostname to OVF template using OVF property "--prop:hostname=some_hostname" while importing using OVF tool. The OVF template must have mechanism ('open-vm-tools' is one such example) to read this OVF property and set its hostname accordingly.
It should also add "127.0.0.1 some_hostname some_hostname.domain_name" entry to /etc/hosts file.
'origin-docker-excluder' and 'origin-excluder' RPMs must be already installed on OVF template.

tr.td: ESX plugin configuration name. ESX plugin is used create underlying VM hosts for OpenShift cluster setup by importing OVF templates.
Name of the datastore to be used.
Name of the host where virtual machines will be imported.
Absoulte path to the directory where OVF packages are stored.

The name of the OpenShift project to which the services and deployments should be deployed. If the project does not exist, it will be created during service deployment.The project name must match the regex [a-z0-9]([-a-z0-9]*[a-z0-9])? (e.g. 'my-name' or '123-abc')
The name of service account to create after OpenShift cluster is setup.Service account name must match the regex [a-z0-9]([-a-z0-9]*[a-z0-9])?(\.[a-z0-9]([-a-z0-9]*[a-z0-9])?)* (e.g. 'example.com')
Prefix to be prepended to VM names and their hostnames to uniquely distiguish from other OpenShift setups.
Name OpenShift plugin configaration to create after OpenShift cluster is setup.
Memory in MB for master VM(s).
Number of CPUs for master VM(s).
Memory in MB for node VMs.
Number of CPUs for node VMs.

Indicates which OpenShift topology to deploy.Following topologies are supported:
Minimal (1 Master, 1 Etcd, both on same machine)
Multiple Etcd (1 Master, 3 Etcd, Master and Etcd on saperate machines)
Multiple Etcd + HAProxy (3 Masters, 3 Etcd, 1 HAProxy)
Number of nodes to add to OpenShift cluster.
Domain name to use for imported OpenShift VMs.(e.g. xyz.yourcompany.com)
The user ansible will use to login to VMs.This user should have passwordless SSH access preconfigured to imported VMs.

div.p: This procedure deploys a service, creating or updating pod definitions, service and deployment in the OpenShift project on the cluster. The OpenShift project(namespace) is created if it does not exist.

tr.td: The name of the service in Deploy that encapsulates the service to be deployed on the OpenShift cluster.
The name of the project that the service belongs to. In case of an application-level service it also owns the application.
The name of the application that the service belongs to. Not applicable for a top-level service.
Revision Id of the application version that the service belongs to.
The name of the cluster in Deploy that encapsulates the OpenShift cluster on which the service is to be deployed.
The name of the project that the cluster belongs to if it is a top-level project cluster. Or the name of the project that the environment belongs to if it is an environment-scoped cluster.
The name of the environment that the cluster belongs to. Not applicable for a top-level project cluster.
